I don't think it's good to dismiss anyone's ideas, but De Garis has 
a kind of kook reputation in the academic community.  He promised 
a "brain" by some date like 1999...of course it didn't happen and 
there were lots of excuses.  It seems he thought if you just stick 
as much new-AI stuff together in a massive parallel system, a brain 
would pop out.  

ken   

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." 
<jim_oflaherty_jr@y...> wrote:
> Ian,
> 
> After reading most of the article (I skimmed some), I thought it 
was interesting.  Ultimately,
> though, from what I read he is using a purely boolean approach to 
his activation mechanism (below
> < 2 does not fire, > 1 does fire).  Without smooth activation 
functions, it means the evolved
> network by its nature must then create smoothness where it is 
needed IN THE CONNECTIVITY.  That
> seems very inefficient.
> 
> It is an interesting experiment.  I would have to see it perform 
over the long term to be
> convinced the results were equavalent to using a smooth activation 
functions (i.e. sigmoidal).  I
> just don't think they are.  Human distinctions in reality of 
fuzzy.  Formal logic is just a small
> subset of human intelligence.  And very few humans use formal 
logic.  And a pretty large number of
> these produce "valuable" solutions to problems.
> 
> Then the guy kind of lost me with his whole "Terran/Artilect" 
discussion at the end.  I was not
> prepared for that.  I then became all that much more suspicious he 
is just another "over-the-top
> dreamer", scaling up a very simple view of logic as the basis 
for "artificial intelligence" - a
> way over-abused term.  :^)
> 
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> --- Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> 
> > Hi,
> > 	This seems to be a nice mix of ANN, GA and CA, and he's 
doing it all in 
> > hardware...
> > 
> > http://www.cs.usu.edu/~degaris/papers/biomim.html
> > 
> > 	Ian Badcoe
